title: Unlockd's Matt Berriman looks for US legal funding to take on Google
text:
Unlockd founder Matt Berriman is back hunting for funding for a potential court case against Google in the US, after the tech giant crushed his mobile advertising business by blocking it from its app store and AdMob advertising network.

Documents prepared by Mr Berriman's lawyers Mayerson & Hartheimer and seen by The Australian Financial Review indicate that the entrepreneur is hoping to pursue an antitrust case against the big tech company and that the lawyers intend to call the likes of former Google Australia head and current Domain chief executive Jason Pellegrino, former APAC Google head Karim Temsamani and chief executive Sundar Pichai as witnesses, should the case receive funding and proceed to court.

Unlockd founder Matt Berriman is going after Google in the US. Arsineh Houspian

Mr Berriman said the amount of funding required would depend on how long the case ran for, but he was in discussion with "massive global funds" with the resources to fund it until the end, even if it was drawn out.

"I'd be surprised if [the court case] isn't launched in the next couple of months," he said.

"The world has changed since early 2018 when Google unlawfully shut down Unlockd. There is ACCC investigations, US Senate enquiries, fines being handed down globally everywhere – the world (and regulators) have come around to the fact that anti-trust behaviour is not only bad for business, but the wider community and ultimately consumers and future innovation."
description: Unlockd founder Matt Berriman has not given up on his fight against tech giant Google.
